scenario.description: What are the confirmed health benefits of vitamin D supplementation across different populations?

motivatingExample.trigger: Epoch Times headline: 'Vitamin D Deficiency Linked to Higher Risk of Early-Onset Dementia' (August 2025)
motivatingExample.userConfusion: Users panic, can't distinguish LOW vitamin D (deficiency) from supplementation effects
motivatingExample.productSolution: Filtered Wikipedia showing only claims meeting user-defined confidence threshold

parameters.population: General adult population, with age-specific subgroups

filteredSummary.description: At 70% threshold, 3 well-established health benefits are confirmed. 3 claims remain uncertain and require more research.

retainedClaims.claim: Vitamin D supplementation prevents rickets in children
retainedClaims.evidenceSummary: 5 meta-analyses, 50+ years of research, mechanistic understanding confirmed

prior.basis: High prior due to mechanistic plausibility (known vitamin deficiency disease), vitamin D's role in calcium metabolism well-established

evidence.factor: Historical data (1920s-1950s): Rickets eliminated in populations with vitamin D supplementation
evidence.reasoning: Natural experiment showed dramatic effect. If supplementation truly prevents rickets, very likely we'd see elimination when implemented. Strong historical evidence.

evidence.factor: Modern meta-analyses (5 studies): Consistent effect across populations, no credible null results
evidence.reasoning: Replication over 50+ years confirms effect. No plausible alternative explanations. Mechanism fully understood.

outcome.effectSize: Near-complete prevention with adequate supplementation (>400 IU/day)
outcome.clinicalSignificance: High - prevents debilitating bone disease in children
outcome.populationBenefit: Universal benefit in populations with low sun exposure

retainedClaims.claim: Vitamin D supplementation reduces fracture risk in elderly adults (age 75+)
retainedClaims.evidenceSummary: 3 large RCTs (n>5,000), 2 meta-analyses, consistent effect in target population

prior.basis: Moderate prior - bone health mechanism known, but efficacy in preventing fractures uncertain
prior.source: Base rate from vitamin supplementation trials

evidence.factor: Chapuy et al. (1992) RCT (n=3,270): 43% reduction in hip fractures with vitamin D + calcium
evidence.reasoning: Large, well-designed RCT showed substantial benefit in elderly women. If effect real, expect 85% detection rate in powered trial.

evidence.factor: VITAL trial (2022) elderly subgroup: Confirmed benefit in adults >75, null in younger adults
evidence.reasoning: Independent replication in different population. Age-specific effect strengthens confidence that this is real, targeted benefit.

outcome.effectSize: 20-40% reduction in fracture risk (depends on baseline vitamin D status)
outcome.clinicalSignificance: Moderate to high - prevents costly, debilitating fractures in elderly
outcome.populationBenefit: Targeted benefit in adults >75, especially those with low baseline vitamin D

retainedClaims.claim: Vitamin D supplementation reduces all-cause mortality in adults over 75
retainedClaims.evidenceSummary: Zhang et al. (2019) meta-analysis (8 RCTs, n=42,000), age-specific effect

prior.basis: Uncertain prior - mortality is complex outcome with many confounders. Moderate starting point.
prior.source: Base rate for vitamin supplementation mortality effects

evidence.factor: VITAL trial (general population, ages 50-80): No mortality benefit in younger adults
evidence.reasoning: Null result in general population weakens confidence. If effect exists in elderly, surprising not to see signal in 50-80 age range.

evidence.factor: Zhang meta-analysis (elderly >75 subgroup): Consistent mortality reduction across 8 RCTs in this age group
evidence.reasoning: Strong evidence for age-specific effect. Multiple RCTs converge. If real effect in elderly, expect 90% detection in meta-analysis.

outcome.effectSize: 7-15% reduction in all-cause mortality (varies by baseline status)
outcome.clinicalSignificance: Moderate - extends lifespan in high-risk elderly population
outcome.populationBenefit: Targeted to adults >75 with deficiency or insufficiency

removedClaims.claim: Low vitamin D levels are associated with higher dementia risk
removedClaims.evidenceSummary: Observational studies only, Grade B-C evidence
removedClaims.removalReason: 65% < 70% threshold. Association doesn't prove causation. Reverse causation and confounding not ruled out.
uncertainties: Reverse causation possible: dementia → less sun exposure → lower vitamin D
Confounding by healthy lifestyle (people with higher vitamin D may have healthier lifestyles overall)
No RCTs testing supplementation for dementia prevention yet completed

removedClaims.removalReason: 50% < 70% threshold. Finnish RCT showed non-significant trend but underpowered. Needs larger trials.
uncertainties: Only one RCT completed, underpowered (only 45 dementia cases in 5 years)
Observational studies show 40% reduction but subject to self-selection bias
Mechanistic plausibility exists (vitamin D receptors in brain) but doesn't guarantee clinical benefit
Needs definitive RCT (n>10,000, 200+ dementia cases) to resolve uncertainty

removedClaims.claim: Vitamin D supplementation prevents cancer in general population
removedClaims.evidenceSummary: VITAL trial (n=25,871) showed no cancer prevention benefit
removedClaims.removalReason: 30% < 70% threshold. Large RCT definitively showed no effect.
uncertainties: VITAL trial was definitive: no cancer benefit in well-designed RCT
Some observational studies showed associations, but VITAL disproved them
Mechanistic plausibility exists, but doesn't translate to clinical benefit
Effect unlikely based on strongest available evidence

sources.citation: Chapuy MC, et al. (1992). Vitamin D3 and calcium to prevent hip fractures in elderly women. N Engl J Med, 327(23), 1637-1642.
Zhang Y, et al. (2019). Association between vitamin D supplementation and mortality: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ, 366, l4673.
Manson JE, et al. (2022). VITAL trial: Vitamin D supplements and prevention of cancer and cardiovascular disease. N Engl J Med, 380(1), 33-44.
Huang Y, et al. (2025). Vitamin D deficiency and risk of dementia: A systematic review and dose-response meta-analysis. Nutrition, 115, 112163.
Lönnroos E, et al. (2025). Vitamin D supplementation and cognitive decline: Finnish Vitamin D Trial. Alzheimer's Dement.

provenanceAndLimitations.notSubmittedByAuthority: NOT submitted by FDA, NIH, Endocrine Society, or any official medical authority
potentialBiases: Some studies industry-funded (though effect size similar)
howToVerify: Search PubMed: 'vitamin D supplementation RCT meta-analysis'
Review Endocrine Society 2024 Clinical Practice Guidelines
Consult your physician before starting supplementation
provenanceAndLimitations.updateMechanism: Quarterly review when new large RCTs published
provenanceAndLimitations.transparencyCommitment: All Bayesian reasoning disclosed. All sources cited. Conservative probability defaults used.
